hero.title: Pixan Chenes
hero.subtitle: Economy with soul, community with future.
hero.description: Pixan Chenes is a Maya cooperative that protects the jungle, cares for bees and builds a dignified future for our communities.
hero.visitors: People who have visited the site

aboutUs.title: Who are we?
aboutUs.description: Pixan means 'soul' in the Maya language and Chenes refers to the wells of our region. We were born in 2020 with the conviction that, from the community, we can change our destiny. We are five Maya communities working together to defend life, culture and the future of our people.

purpose.title: Our purpose
purpose.description: We want our Maya communities to live with dignity, without abandoning their land or culture. We dream of a sustainable development model where tradition and innovation walk together. When you get to know Pixan Chenes, you will feel the heartbeat of a people that resists, cares and stands firm.

values.title: Our values
values.subtitle: The Principles that Guide Our Journey

items.title: Respect for life, land and our identity
items.description: We honor all forms of life and protect our Maya cultural heritage, keeping alive the sacred connection with mother earth.

items.title: Equity as the basis of development
items.description: We believe that true progress is only possible when everyone has the same opportunities to grow and prosper.

items.title: Community participation
items.description: We foster the active participation of all voices in making decisions that affect our common future.

items.title: Solidary linkage
items.description: We build bridges of collaboration and mutual support between communities, strengthening our network of solidarity.

items.title: Ecological care
items.description: We protect and regenerate our ecosystem, practicing a harmonious relationship with the nature that sustains us.

items.title: Dignity
items.description: We defend the right of every person to live with honor, respect and the necessary conditions for a full life.

liveValues.title: Lived Values
liveValues.description: These values are not just ideals, but are reflected in each of our daily actions and community decisions. They are the heart that beats in every project and the compass that guides our work.

practices.title: In Every Decision
practices.description: Our values guide every choice we make as a community, from the smallest to the most transcendental.

practices.title: In Every Project
practices.description: Every initiative we undertake is imbued with these principles, ensuring coherence between what we believe and what we do.

practices.title: For the Future
practices.description: We work so that these values are the legacy we leave to the next generations of our Maya community.

communities.title: Communities that make up Pixan Chenes
communities.description: Five indigenous Maya communities in Hopelchén, Campeche:
communities.list: San Francisco Suc Tuc, Sahcabchén, Yakché Akal, Xcupil and Oxá.

activities.title: What do we do?
items: Elaboration and sale of basic products
Training workshops for youth and women

leadership.title: Community leadership
leadership.description: The cooperative is led by indigenous Maya women, who head the organization with commitment, wisdom and vision. They are the heart of the project and an example of transformation from the collective.

achievements.title: Our achievements
achievements.description: We have constituted the cooperative, articulated NODESS together with IPN and other institutions, and developed innovative projects such as an application for honey collection management. These alliances have strengthened our productive and organizational capacities.

future.title: Our future
future.description: In 5 years we dream of being a model community of development with identity, exporting products with Maya traceability, leading in reforestation and carbon bonds, responsible tourism, community biotechnology and transformative education.

allies.title: Linkage and allies
allies.description: Institutions such as the National Polytechnic Institute, Suc Tuc Community High School, Fertile Land and the Xcupil Comisariado, among others, accompany and strengthen our path.

joinUs.title: Join Pixan Chenes
joinUs.description: We want those who visit us to participate actively: acquiring our products, buying environmental certificates and thus supporting reforestation and community development.

quality.title: Quality and authenticity
quality.description: Artisanal processes and ancestral knowledge with technical accompaniment.

technology.title: Technologies
technology.description: Combination of traditional practices and technological tools.

benefits.title: Benefits
benefits.description: In implementation process, with growing impact.

recipients.title: Recipients
recipients.description: Communities, youth, women, institutions, companies and conscious consumers.

OurEssence.title: Our Essence
OurEssence.description: We are the heartbeat of the Maya people in the Chenes region.
OurEssence.description1: Pixan Chenes is the fruit of the union of indigenous women and men, guardians of an ancient territory. We emerge as a seed of hope in the face of challenges.
OurEssence.description2: We have the firm purpose of writing our own destiny through self-management, respect for our mother earth and the recovery of our historical memory.
OurEssence.description3: We are not just a cooperative; we are a living museum, a space of cultural resistance and a tangible model of regenerative community development.
OurEssence.description4: We fuse the deep ancestral knowledge of our grandparents with modern science and the principles of social economy, to create abundance and well-being for all families.

OurReality.title: Our Reality
OurReality.subtitle: The Challenge We Turn Into Opportunity
OurReality.contextDescription: Living in the Chenes region is a daily struggle for dignity. We are a community where more than 80% of the population is indigenous and we face harsh realities:

indigenous.title: Indigenous Population
indigenous.description: More than 80% of our community is indigenous

drought.title: Months of Drought
drought.description: More than six months a year without sufficient water

challenges.title: Drought
challenges.description: Our constant enemy for more than six months a year

dailyChallenges.title: Daily Challenges
dailyChallenges.description1: Drought is our constant enemy for more than six months a year. We don't have sufficient irrigation systems and bringing water to our homes is an exhaustive task.
dailyChallenges.description2: This reality affects our land, our wildlife and our livelihood.
dailyChallenges.note: The constant struggle for basic resources that determines our daily life

opportunity.title: But in the face of adversity, a historic opportunity rises.

mayaTrain.title: Maya Train
mayaTrain.description: The Maya Train projection anticipates the arrival of more than 5 million tourists per year. The question is not whether change will come, but who will benefit from it.
mayaTrain.imageCaption: Image of the Maya Train project and its impact on the region

ourResponse.title: We Have the Answer

naturalTreasure.title: Natural Treasure
naturalTreasure.description: Expanses of land within the jungle that are a treasure of conservation and culture

responsibility.title: With Responsibility
responsibility.description: Ready to welcome the world with responsibility and respect for our culture

strategicAlliance.title: Strategic Alliance
strategicAlliance.description: For those who want to invest in true, sustainable and fair development

ourResponse.finalMessage: Pixan Chenes is our organized response. We transform difficulty into purpose and threat into determination. We don't ask for charity; we offer a strategic alliance.

OurMission.title: Our Mission
OurMission.mainDescription: Our mission is to drive the integral and sustainable development of indigenous communities in the Chenes region.
OurMission.dailyWorkTitle: We work day by day to:

commitment.title: Daily Commitment
commitment.description1: Every day we renew our commitment to the land, to our community and to future generations.
commitment.description2: Our mission is not just an ideal, it is a daily practice that transforms lives and territories.

regeneration.title: Regeneration
regeneration.description: Regenerate our soils and forests through syntropic agroforestry systems.

protection.title: Protection
protection.description: Protect wildlife and our sacred Melipona bees.

localEconomy.title: Local Economy
localEconomy.description: Strengthen the local economy through community tourism and marketing of our products.

livingCulture.title: Living Culture
livingCulture.description: Revitalize our culture, language and traditions for future generations.

foodSovereignty.title: Food Sovereignty
foodSovereignty.description: Guarantee food sovereignty for our families.

OurVision.title: Our Vision
OurVision.mainPhrase: We dream of a prosperous Chenes region, where indigenous communities exercise their self-determination, live in harmony with nature and their culture flourishes with pride.
OurVision.lighthouseDescription: In a world of accelerated change, Pixan Chenes stands as a beacon of hope and a replicable model of community development with identity.
OurVision.sustainableFutureDescription: We imagine a future where the jungle and communities grow together, where technology serves tradition and where progress benefits everyone equally.
OurVision.commitmentDescription: We commit to being active guardians of our culture, protectors of our land and builders of a dignified future for the next generations.
OurVision.legacyDescription: More than a vision, it is our daily commitment: to demonstrate that development that respects cultural identity, protects the environment and generates collective well-being is possible.

selfDetermination.title: Self-Determination
selfDetermination.description: Indigenous communities fully exercising their right to self-determination and self-government.

naturalHarmony.title: Natural Harmony
naturalHarmony.description: Life in perfect harmony with nature, respecting and regenerating our environment.

flourishingCulture.title: Flourishing Culture
flourishingCulture.description: Our Maya culture flourishing with pride and being passed on to new generations.

OurVision.collaborationDescription: We expect collaboration from society, businesses and NGOs, contributing to the Mexico Plan.
OurVision.mexicoPlanDescription: Actively contributing to national development through sustainable and replicable community models.

OurPilares.title: Our Pillars
OurPilares.subtitle: The Values that Guide Us
OurPilares.valuesInActionDescription: These pillars are not just beautiful words; they are the foundation of every decision we make and every action we take in our community.
OurPilares.dailyPracticeDescription: Every day we apply these values in our community and family work.
OurPilares.consciousDecisionsDescription: Our pillars guide every important decision in the organization.
OurPilares.lastingLegacyDescription: We work so that these values are the legacy for future generations.

selfManagement.title: Syntropic Self-Management
selfManagement.description: We believe in community organization as the path to create order, abundance and resilience, imitating nature.

ancestralWisdom.title: Ancestral Wisdom
ancestralWisdom.description: Our starting point is the knowledge inherited from our Maya people. It is our compass and our greatest strength.

regeneration.title: Regeneration
regeneration.description: We don't just want to conserve, we want to heal and improve our environment to leave it better than we found it.

genderEquity.title: Gender Equity
genderEquity.description: Our directive is integrated and led by women. We believe in the transformative power of indigenous women.

transparency.title: Transparency and Trust
transparency.description: We act with honesty and provide clear accountability to our community and to those who believe in us.

OurProjects.title: Our Projects
OurProjects.subtitle: Impact and SDGs
OurProjects.introDescription1: Our projects are intimately linked to the Maya worldview, conservation and the recovery of historical memory.
OurProjects.introDescription2: Dignified employment is dedication to caring for the jungle.

beekeeping.title: Maya Beekeeping
beekeeping.description: Our bees are guardians of biodiversity and producers of honey with unique properties thanks to the floral diversity of our jungle.

forest.title: Jungle Route
forest.description: Community ecotourism project that allows visitors to know the Maya jungle in a responsible and educational way.

reforestation.title: Community Reforestation
reforestation.description: Reforestation program that involves the entire community in the recovery and protection of our forests.

crafts.title: Traditional Crafts
crafts.description: Creation of crafts that preserve ancestral Maya techniques and generate dignified income for our families.

agriculture.title: Syntropic Agriculture
agriculture.description: Agricultural system that imitates nature, combining traditional crops with modern sustainable techniques.

education.title: Community Education
education.description: Educational programs that strengthen Maya cultural identity and prepare new generations for the future.

sdgSection.title: Sustainable Development Goals
sdgSection.description: We work directly towards the UN Sustainable Development Goals, contributing to a fairer and more sustainable world.

impactSection.title: Real Impact, Lasting Change
impactSection.description1: Each of our projects generates measurable impact in the lives of our families and in the conservation of our territory.
impactSection.description2: They are not just economic projects; they are expressions of our worldview and tools for the recovery of our historical memory.
impactSection.quote: True development comes from within, with respect and harmony

OurEvents.title: Calendar of Events
OurEvents.description: Our year is woven around events that celebrate our culture and generate local economy

womenDay.title: March - International Women's Day
womenDay.description: An event to recognize and strengthen the leadership of women in the area, with forums and cultural activities.

beeDay.title: May - International Bee Day Event
beeDay.subtitle: Our emblematic event (May 20-24, 2026)
beeDay.description: A series of cultural, recreational, economic, folkloric, ceremonial, gastronomic and sports activities to strengthen the social fabric and connect us with the world.

sports.title: Sports Activities
sports.description: "Minimundialito" soccer for all ages and schools from more than 10 communities, basketball, volleyball and traditional games.

culture.title: Cultural Expression
culture.description: War bands, batucada, traditional dances, strength competitions and ceremonial event.

academic.title: Academic Space
academic.description: Conferences on Maya beekeeping, solidarity economy and community development.

gastronomy.title: Traditional Gastronomy
gastronomy.description: Showcase of Maya cuisine with local ingredients and ancestral techniques.

ancestorsDay.title: November - Day of the Dead (Hanal Pixán)
ancestorsDay.description: Ancestral Maya ceremony to honor ancestors and keep our cultural tradition alive.

treeDay.title: June - International Tree Day
treeDay.description: A call to action for reforestation work in our region, open to volunteers.

hanalPixan.title: October/November - Hannal Pixan
hanalPixan.description: A deep and respectful experience about the Maya Day of the Dead tradition, open to the community and visitors.

christmasFair.title: December - Christmas Fair
christmasFair.description: A community celebration (2025) that will evolve into a public fair (2026) for the sale of local products and crafts.

projects.title: Projects
projects.grandparentsAndYoungPeople: We learn from our grandparents, we emprend with our young people from the school

login.title: Sign In
login.description: Enter your email below to sign in to your account

logout.error: Error logging out. Please try again.

hero.communitySupport: With community support we have achieved

testimonials.title: Community Contributor
testimonials.description: These people are already part of the rescue of the Selva Maya. You can be one of them too.

explanation.title: What is a Seed Certificate?
explanation.description: A Seed Certificate is a document that certifies that a plant has been planted in a specific location.
explanation.subtitle: What does a certificate look like?

benefit_reforestation.title: Direct reforestation
benefit_reforestation.description: Contributes directly to the reforestation of endemic species.

benefit_certificate.title: Verifiable certificate
benefit_certificate.description: You get a verifiable digital recognition, with a unique code.

benefit_cultural_preservation.title: Cultural preservation
benefit_cultural_preservation.description: You contribute to preserving the traditional Mayan house, fresher and more sustainable.

benefit_beekeeping_support.title: Beekeeping support
benefit_beekeeping_support.description: Promotes local beekeeping and sustainable economy.

timeline.title: Certificate Process
timeline.description: Each certificate represents a real process that takes more than a year and requires daily effort. This is how it happens:

step_1.title: Seed Selection
step_1.description: The best seeds of native trees are selected, chosen for their value in honey production and traditional Maya housing.

step_2.title: Nursery Care
step_2.subtitle: 10 months
step_2.description: Trees are watered daily, cared for, moved, bagged, and transported when ready.

step_3.title: Transport and Planting
step_3.description: When the rains arrive, the trees are carried to reforestation zones—rugged terrain with challenging conditions.

step_4.title: Monitoring and Replacement
step_4.subtitle: 12 months
step_4.description: Each tree is monitored to ensure it survives. If it doesn’t, it is replanted.

map.title: What did the areas look like before deforestation?
map.description: Move the bar to compare what the area looked like in 2000 before deforestation and compared to now 2025

header.title: Certificate Acquisition Options
header.description: Choose the way that suits you best to contribute to our reforestation project and help plant trees in the Mayan lands of Campeche.

donation.name: Free Donation

features.project_support: Support for the general care of the project

donation.idealFor: Those who just want to support without complications

certificate.name: Tree Certificate
certificate.description: Your tree, your certificate, your impact
certificate.idealFor: Businesses, meaningful gifts, direct connection with the cause

location.title: Project Location
location.description: All trees are planted in Mayan lands of Campeche, Mexico, contributing to local reforestation and the well-being of indigenous communities.
location.verified: Verified project • Care guaranteed for over a year

header.title: Do you have questions about the project?
header.description: Here you’ll find answers to the most common questions about our reforestation project in Campeche.

text.noQuestionsFoundDescription: No questions found that match your search. Try with other terms or check all categories.

difference.question: What’s the difference between donating and buying a certificate?
difference.answer: Donating is a free contribution, with no need to register or receive anything in return. On the other hand, buying a certificate means you acquire a digital document representing a real planted tree, with tracking and personalization options.

cost.question: How much does a certificate cost?
cost.answer: Each certificate costs $350 MXN, which covers the full process from seed selection to over a year of tree monitoring.

what_receive.question: What do I receive when I buy a certificate?
what_receive.answer: You’ll receive a personalized digital certificate that includes all your tree’s information and tracking options.

tree_types.question: What types of trees are planted?
tree_types.answer: We plant endemic species that are useful to the Maya community, carefully selected to support biodiversity, honey production, and traditional construction.

money_destination.question: Where does my money go?
money_destination.answer: Your contribution is used transparently across the entire reforestation and community development process.
details: Fair payment to the community caring for them

multiple_certificates.question: Can I buy more than one certificate at a time?
multiple_certificates.answer: Yes, you can purchase as many certificates as you want in a single transaction. You’ll receive an individual certificate for each tree acquired.

tree_tracking.question: Can I track my tree?
tree_tracking.answer: Yes. When you buy a certificate, you can request personalized tracking that includes periodic photos, health status, and progress updates.

donation_registration.question: Do I need to register to donate?
donation_registration.answer: No. Free donations don’t require registration or login. Just choose the amount and that’s it.

purchase_registration.question: And to buy a certificate?
purchase_registration.answer: Yes. Buying certificates requires creating an account or logging in, since a purchase history is generated and certificates are assigned to you.

gift_certificate.question: Can I give a certificate as a gift?
gift_certificate.answer: Yes. You can buy a certificate and enter the name of the person you want to give it to. Soon you'll be able to include a personalized message.

certificate_delivery_time.question: Will I receive the certificate immediately?
certificate_delivery_time.answer: You’ll receive your digital certificate as soon as your payment is processed. In some cases, it might take a few minutes.

physical_certificate.question: Can I get a physical certificate?
physical_certificate.answer: For now, we only issue digital certificates. We’re working on offering an optional physical version in the future.

cta.title: Didn't find what you were looking for?
cta.description: We have more frequently asked questions and a search function to help you better

Metadata.title: Pixan Chenes - Mayan Cooperative | Environmental Certificates, Reforestation and Sustainable Development
Metadata.description: Pixan Chenes is a Mayan cooperative in Hopelchén, Campeche, dedicated to beekeeping, reforestation, and solidarity economy. We offer digital environmental certificates, Mayan honey, and sustainable products that empower indigenous communities and protect the rainforest.
Metadata.keywords: Pixan Chenes, Mayan cooperative, environmental certificates, reforestation certificates, solidarity economy, Campeche reforestation, Mayan beekeeping, Mayan honey, sustainable products, indigenous communities, community development, Maya rainforest, environmental conservation, carbon credits, product traceability, community tourism, responsible tourism, Hopelchén Campeche, cultural identity products, natural cosmetics, apitherapy, sustainable agriculture

about.title: About Pixan Chenes
about.description: Pixan Chenes is a Mayan indigenous cooperative formed by five communities in Hopelchén, Campeche. We defend the rainforest, care for bees, and offer sustainable alternatives such as digital environmental certificates and culturally rooted products.

NotFound.title: Page not found
NotFound.subtitle: The page you're looking for doesn't exist
NotFound.description: Sorry, the page you're trying to visit hasn't been created yet or has been moved to another location. In the meantime, you can explore our available content.

definition.title: What is NODESS?
definition.description: NODESS (Node for Promoting Social and Solidarity Economy) is an initiative of the National Institute of Social Economy (INAES) that seeks to create collaboration networks between communities, educational institutions and organizations to strengthen productive projects with social and cultural impact.

integration.title: NODESS Integration
integration.description: In our case, NODESS is made up of the Pixan Chenes Cooperative, UPIIT of the National Polytechnic Institute, the Suc Tuc Community High School, the Xcupil Commissariat in Campeche, and the Tierra Fértil Civil Association of Tlaxcala.

objective.title: Our Objective
objective.description: Together we work to unite academic knowledge, community organization and social solidarity, in order to generate development opportunities that respect cultural identity, boost the local economy and promote collective well-being.

documentation.title: Official Documentation
documentation.description: Learn more details about the NODESS project and its implementation in our community.

apitoxin.title: Device for Apitoxin Extraction
apitoxin.intro: Within the NODESS framework, this project represents an exceptional example of collaboration between academia, community, and the Pixan Chenes cooperative.
apitoxin.imageAlt: Apitoxin extraction device developed by UPIIT student

developer.title: Developer
developer.name: Harold Bryan Espinoza Sánchez - Student at the Interdisciplinary Professional Unit of Engineering Tlaxcala campus

benefits.title: Innovations and Benefits:
benefits.list: Safe and efficient method for obtaining apitoxin|Substance with pharmaceutical and cosmetic applications|Strengthens local productive chain|Diversifies economic opportunities|Promotes sustainability of Mayan beekeeping

impact.title: Community Impact
impact.description: This project demonstrates how UPIIT and the Pixan Chenes cooperative foster entrepreneurial spirit, promoting innovative solutions that link scientific knowledge with community development.

website.title: Pixan Chenes Website
website.intro: A digital tool that gives greater visibility to the cooperative's activities and strengthens the online presence of Mayan communities.

developer.title: Developer
developer.name: Diego Castro Elvira - Graduate student in Artificial Intelligence, UPIIT Tlaxcala

features.title: Main features:
features.list: Spreading achievements and activities|Strengthening community communication|Product sales channel|Platform for receiving donations|Global visibility for the cooperative

impact.title: Project Impact
impact.description: Reflects how NODESS fosters entrepreneurial spirit and collaboration, leveraging technology to drive economic and social growth of Mayan communities.

pajaroToh.title: The Legend of the Toh Bird
pajaroToh.intro: Video produced within the framework of NODESS: PIXAN–UPIIT Connection. Development and Empowerment of Women and Indigenous Mayan Communities, an alliance between UPIIT, the Pixan Chenes cooperative, the Suc Tuc Community High School, the Xcupil Commissariat, and the Tierra Fértil Civil Association.

students.title: Community High School Students:
students.list: Julissa Itzel Ramírez Mendoza|Aura Daniela León Naal|Suri Saddai Dzul Cuencas

legend.title: Legend:
legend.name: Hadasa Abigail Ramírez Mendoza (Maya community resident)

aiStudents.title: UPIIT AI Career Students:
aiStudents.list: Samuel Alejandro Torres Oropeza – Artificial Intelligence student|Navil Pineda Rugerio – Artificial Intelligence intern, UPIIT–IPN

callToAction.description: Discover the complete story of the Toh Bird Legend with traditional Maya narration.

culturalValue.title: 🎯 Cultural Value
culturalValue.description: This collaboration shows how technology and tradition can unite to preserve and disseminate Maya cultural heritage.

impact.title: Community Impact
impact.description: This is an example showing that through inter-institutional and community collaboration, integrating students, teachers, social organizations, and local authorities, cultural revaluation, sustainable development, and collective learning can be promoted, creating real empowerment opportunities for communities, values aligned with the PDI of the National Polytechnic Institute.

GrandparentsAndYoungPeople.title: We Learn from Grandparents, We Undertake with Young People from School
GrandparentsAndYoungPeople.subtitle: Dr. Yadira Rivera Espinoza

doctor.title: About Dr. Yadira Rivera Espinoza
doctor.description: Dr. Yadira Rivera Espinoza, **former director of the National School of Biological Sciences (ENCB) of the National Polytechnic Institute**, is a biotechnologist, entrepreneur, researcher, and academic at the **Interdisciplinary Professional Unit of Engineering Tlaxcala Campus (IPN)**. She has contributed to the training of hundreds of students in **Biochemical, Biotechnological, Artificial Intelligence, and Data Science Engineering**, in addition to supervising master's and doctoral theses in sciences. With her experience, she has promoted innovative projects that link science and entrepreneurship with social impact.
doctor.commitment: Her commitment to the Mayan community arises from the direct call of the founders of the **Pixan Chenes** cooperative, who invited her to put her knowledge and her proposal **“Love for the Community”** (presented to the Presidency of the Republic during her tenure at the ENCB) at the service of the Mayan communities.

program.title: The Program
program.description: The program 'We Learn from Grandparents, We Undertake with Young People from School,' designed by Dr. Yadira Rivera Espinoza, emerges within the framework of the **Social and Solidarity Economy Promotion Hub (NODESS)**. **The program will start in October 2025**.

communities.title: Beneficiary Communities
communities.description: The program will begin with students from the communities of **Suc Tuc and Xcupil**, strengthening intergenerational ties and promoting local sustainable development.

modules.title: Program Modules (6 Modules)
modules.list: Human development and leadership: Self-awareness and purpose|Community work and project design: Needs assessment in family/community and Social Canvas| Research with Artificial Intelligence: Information search, idea generation, and support materials|Calls and financing: Reading guidelines, requirements, and compiling files|Project execution and monitoring: Implementation, follow-up, and alliances|Impact evaluation and socialization: Community fair, systematization of learning, and success stories

objective.title: Program Objective
objective.description: Its objective is to strengthen intergenerational learning, foster community entrepreneurship, and provide preparation for managing projects according to the needs of each Mayan family.

contact.title: Contact Information
contact.description: If your community is interested in this program, send us an email to **pixancheness@gmail.com** or **yriverae@ipn.com**.

CTC.title: Technical Advisory Council (CTC) Pixan Chenes
CTC.subtitle: Multidisciplinary body for community support and strengthening
CTC.description: The Technical Advisory Council (CTC) Pixan Chenes is a multidisciplinary body composed of individuals from various specialties who collaborate voluntarily, by invitation of the cooperative, to support and strengthen the development of the Mayan communities of Campeche.

intro.description1: Their work combines scientific, technological, ancestral, and social knowledge, which allows for the generation of proposals with cultural relevance and academic rigor.
intro.description2: The CTC has the internal endorsement of the Assembly and the Community Council of Knowledge and Development of the Cooperative, as well as external recognition from the NODESS of INAES, which guarantees social and institutional legitimacy.

origin.title: Why was it created?
origin.description: It arose as a response to the need for a space for technical advice and support to guide the actions of the Pixan Chenes cooperative and its strategic allies. Its purpose is to promote sustainable projects that generate social well-being, strengthen the solidarity economy, and preserve the Mayan cultural identity.

importance.title: Importance of the CTC
importance.list: It provides a multidisciplinary vision that combines biotechnology, renewable energy, mathematics, social economy, administration, health regulations, and local knowledge.|It generates practical solutions that respond to the real needs of the community.|It strengthens collective work, ensuring that projects are viable, sustainable, and have a social impact.

alignment.title: Alignment with NODESS and INAES
alignment.description: The CTC Pixan Chenes aligns with the NODESS of INAES and the SDGs.
alignment.list: The CTC reflects the multidisciplinarity, intergenerationality, and sustainability focus required by INAES and the 2030 Agenda.|It is prepared to promote projects in food, health, energy, environment, and economic development, all with community relevance and scaling potential.

functions.title: Main functions
functions.list: Technical and scientific advice: In biotechnology, energy, productive processes, and community development.|Support in training: For Mayan youth, women, and producers.|Promotion of sustainable projects: That respect the environment and strengthen cultural identity.|Institutional linkage: Between the Mayan community, academia, government, and civil society.|Social and productive innovation: Generating replicable models for other communities.

members.title: CTC Members
members.description: The CTC Pixan Chenes is made up of a diverse group of academics, researchers, inventors, specialists, technicians, and young students representing different disciplines and backgrounds, all united by the commitment to contribute their knowledge and experience to the service of the Mayan community.
members.list: Dra. Yadira Rivera Espinoza: Drives the union between science, technology, and social development. Her vision unites academia and communities to open paths for empowerment. She coordinates the Node's activities.|Dr. Filiberto Vázquez Dávila: Inventor of the voting ink, recognized worldwide, a symbol of science at the service of society. His scientific legacy demonstrates that innovation can transform democratic life.|M.C. Yoja Gallardo Navarro: Pioneer in food technology with international social impact. Her vocation for service has led her to transform communities in Mexico and Cuba.|Dra. Edén Cano Sampedro: Scientist passionate about functional foods and their social impact. She promotes knowledge with practical application for collective well-being.|Dra. Astrid Delfina Toache Pérez: Researcher focused on sustainable industrial processes. She stands out for her commitment to the reuse of electronic materials.|Dra. Steffanie Jiménez Flores: Academic dedicated to harnessing solar energy. She believes in clean energy as an engine for sustainable development.|M. en C. Silvia Sánchez Márquez: Expert in mathematical models that explain the complexity of the real world. She unites science and prediction to anticipate development scenarios.|Dra. Marina Olivia Franco Hernández: Trainer of generations of students and environmental defender. Her career combines teaching and research with a strong environmental commitment.|Ing. Carlos Cahuic Tzel: With experience in social programs like Sembrando Vida, he has supported the Mayan communities in building collective projects. He is one of the pillars in the formation of the Pixan Chenes Cooperative.|Lic. Nelson Sarabia Huchín: With Mayan roots, he embodies the values of the social and solidarity economy. Recognized community leader committed to his land.|Lic. Yamili Sarabia Huchín: Entrepreneur and academic who represents the spirit of local innovation. Her leadership focuses on strengthening community organization.|IBQ Noé Lizárraga Camacho: Academic with extensive experience in health regulation. His constant support since the founding of Pixan Chenes ensures solidity and professionalism at every stage.|M. en A. Víctor Hugo Luna Acevedo: Master in Administration in Education Management and Development and Biochemical Engineer. His structured vision and organizational capacity have strengthened the activities of the Pixan Chenes Cooperative and the Rethinking Mayan Culture Seminar.|ISA Nelson Castillo Alemán: Environmental engineer with experience in the energy and educational sectors. Committed to society, he promotes teamwork and sustainability.|LM Tito Alberto Huerta Espinoza: Linkage manager and designer of the Pixan Chenes cooperative logo. Contributes experience in training and institutional support.|Diego Castro Elvira: Young entrepreneur in Artificial Intelligence. Develops and manages the cooperative's website with digital innovation.|Samuel Alejandro Torres Oropeza: Creative Artificial Intelligence student. Co-creator of the Toh bird video, uniting technology and tradition.|Harold Bryan Espinosa Sánchez: Inventor and biotechnology student. Designs a device for apitoxin extraction to serve beekeepers.

CTC.closingMessage: The CTC Pixan Chenes: Where science and tradition unite to build a sustainable future.

Seminario.title: Seminar: Rethinking Maya Culture

importance.title: Seminar Importance
importance.description: The Seminar Rethinking Maya Culture emerges as a space for dialogue and reflection within the framework of participatory action-research, where the voice of Maya communities from Hopelchén, Campeche, takes center stage. Its importance lies in allowing recognition and visibility of the current role of Maya culture in sustainability, understood not only as environmental care, but also as the preservation of identity, community practices and ancestral knowledge.

approach.title: Co-creation Approach
approach.description: The relevance of the seminar lies in its knowledge co-creation approach: community representatives, academics and social actors meet in a horizontal dialogue space that promotes the collective construction of alternatives for the country's economic, cultural and social development.

themes.title: Proposed Themes
themes.list: community strengths, bee challenges, indigenous development, Campeche identity, Hanal Pixan

mission.title: Strengthening NODESS Mission
mission.description: This seminar strengthens the NODESS mission by articulating efforts between educational institutions, cooperatives, local authorities and civil organizations, consolidating a support and mutual learning network that enriches both academic and community life.

future.title: Rethinking the Future
future.description: In this way, it becomes a means to rethink the future from the roots of Maya culture, valuing its contribution as a living heritage and as an engine of social innovation.

Seminario.imageAlt: Rethinking Maya Culture Seminar - Maya communities in dialogue
Seminario.imageCaption: Meeting of ancestral knowledge and academic knowledge for sustainable development

Footer.description: Maya cooperative in Campeche that protects the jungle, practices sustainable beekeeping and offers reforestation certificates.
